noun.description: In south-west England: a ford across a rhine. Now archaic and historical.

origin: Late 15th century (in an earlier sense). From Anglo-Norman plungeon and Middle French plongeon a kind of diving bird from post-classical Latin plumbion-, plumbio, ultimately from classical Latin plumbum lead, perhaps via an unattested post-classical Latin verb *plumbiare to dive; compare -oon.
